reviewText: This movie is absolutely awesome. I started off watching this movie expecting to be bored for the next 3 hours of my life, but surpringly, I'm glad to say that I was wrong. Brad Pitt as Achilles makes this entire movie worth watching anyway, but the fact that he totally kicked @ss was an added bonus. Not only is he extremely HOTT!, but he can also pull off playing a Greek legend like a charm. Quite frankly, I haven't seen Brad carry a movie this great in quite some time, so I am most certainly impressed. I also must admit that I underestimated Eric Bana's character "Hector" as well because he actually played a great warrior. I was also shocked to see Peter O'Toole because he's definitely a face that I haven't seen in a long time, and he still looks great for his age might I add. I can honestly say that the only character that I was a little diappointed with was Orlando Bloom's character "Paris". It's a good thing that he had so many other stronger characters supporting his role because clearly he was just the weak link of the movie. Don't get me wrong, I like Orlando Bloom, I really do, but his character just wasn't in the same league as the others. To keep it short, I would definitely recommend that anyone who hasn't seen this movie check it out, and then buy it for your collection. I know I plan to.

reviewText: Although Troy is clearly a popcorn flick, not a history lesson, if youre going to spend US$150 million to recreate the Trojan War, you may as well get things right. Instead, Wolfgang Petersen seems content to sling together a mishmash of anachronisms that together give a vague, general sense of antiquity, rather than Troy, 1200 BC.A few of the more annoying examples:The statues in the city of Troy? Wrong (theyre actually replicas of Greek kouroi).The coins? Wrong (coins werent invented until several centuries later).The jewellery worn by the Trojan princesses? Wrong (unless those were family heirlooms, theyre a full millennium too old).The thousand Greek ships that set sail? Wrong (the designs are about four centuries off).The 50-foot high wall that encircles Troy? Wrong (in real life it was a ditch).But enough nit-picking  I could spend all day bitching about the historical inaccuracies and I haven't even started about the mishmash of the story (Cassandra's unheeded warnings coming out of Hector's mouth, Laocoon's lines going to poncy Prince Paris, Aeneas appearing with his dad Anchises but looking a trifle too young and with his son nowhere in sight) but Troy isnt worth getting carpal tunnel syndrome for.So, what else is there besides historical deviations and sweeping shots of a fleet of miniature Greek boats in a large bathtub?On the plus side, any movie that sparks interest in the classics has to be a good thing. The film company executives may beg to differ, but if at least one young person is inspired to pick up the Iliad and the Odyssey because of this film, the millions spent on this lavish production will have been worthwhile.Another plus is that theres plenty of eye candy. When I wasnt wishing I could bitch-slap Helen (Diane Kruger) and her even-girlier Trojan prince, Paris (Orlando Bloom), I was shamelessly ogling Achilles (Brad Pitt), the buffed-up Greek warrior who spends much of his time off the battlefield, either en deshabille or in a Beckham-style sarong, cavorting with his Stockholm Syndrome-suffering Trojan slave girl (Rose Byrne).When you film such well-known stories as the Trojan War, the most important issue becomes how you tell the story, not the story itself, and regrettably, Petersens delivery is neither convincing nor eloquent.The acting too is a let-down, especially that of Priam (Peter OToole), Agamemnon (Brian Cox), and Menelaus (Brendan Gleeson), who shouldve known better than to be content with cardboard caricatures.Id like to say that I didnt like Troy because of the crap special effects, the superfluous liberties taken with generally accepted myth and the negligent research, but in the end I guess what irked me the most about the movie is that the men have much better hair and look so much sexier in short skirts than I do. In the end, that's all you can say about this superficial summer blockbuster.

reviewText: The Illiad gets Hollywood treatment and loses all poetry and awesomeness and what made it a classic of Western Civilization, not surprisingly. My main beef in addition to the theatrical release lacking any emotional depth or characters I cared about at all was that the story was stripped of its crucial mythological underpinnings. Where are the gods? Homer isn't meant to be real history. It'd be like if they did Lord of the Rings without magical wizards...instead Ian McKellen is an old hermit and there's no magical ring. They're just good northern European medieval people fighting an evil league of Roman Catholics, Turks, Middle Eastern peoples and Africans. Anyway. Yes they think Troy existed but that ain't the point of Homer and as far as realism goes (IF that's what they aimed for..) it didn't successfully flesh out ancient Greek life and war. I recall a scene of thousands of cgi spear carriers running across a field and feeling like you do when you're consciously watching a mundane "special effect", not something you feel real or compelling. Ex. of realistic type ancient battle is found here-->Braveheart Poster Movie 11x17 Mel Gibson Sophie Marceau Patrick McGoohan Catherine McCormackand...here: Rome: The Complete First Season. This Troy movie is a pedestrian sword and sandal battle flick. The battles weren't exciting except for a moment when poor Hector must face Achilles.. you had to feel bad for the guy. Achilles himself came across as almost neurotic and whinny but I still didn't care for him. And I think Pitt is a solid actor. My 2 cents. I'd recommend the amazing Rome: The Complete Series for godless, metaphysical free truly gritty realism. You're in the streets with the plebs smelling the body odor and gagging on the overpowering aroma of the sewage and rotting things and you could get shanked, beaten and robbed or worse... and you're also brought into Machiavellian soap opera intrigues of wicked aristocrats. Heck check out the original Clash of the Titans for some good but unabashedly campy Olympian adventure story fun - Laurence Olivier as Zeus!

reviewText: My feelings on Troy are mixed.  While I did enjoy the action/war scenes that reminded me of Lord of the Rings, there was the small detail to the story and plot that just completely blew my mind.  Why, if you are going to make a history epic such as this, would you focus so intently on the characters that the story (which should have been the star of the film) pretty much falls to the wayside?  I think that it has something to do with who you have carrying your story.  If you have actors that are a little less defined in their careers, perhaps you would focus more on the story giving us the way that Homer would have been happy with.  Instead, we headline huge actors to carry the roles and focus more on the shirtless wonders of the world instead of the written word.  It is sad and unforgivable at the same time.To begin, let me tell you what I really liked about this film, which shouldn't take up too much space, but is still worthy of mention.  I loved the grand scale of this film.  When I read Homer's work, I didn't think of this tiny little incident that felt and looked like a back lot to a movie studio.  I wanted epic visions of land, wars, and chaos.  I wanted to be placed right in the action by being transported to the era visually and audibly.  Director Wolfgang Petersen did this with the greatest of ease.  This is a big production film, and he never allowed us to forget that.  Second, I enjoyed the smaller stories of this film.  The hints and references made to the culture at the time that allowed those three years of Latin class, Greek Mythology, and history of Troy seemed to constantly keep a grin on my face and my mind in motion.  It reminded me of Disney's Hercules, one of the most underappreciated Disney films out there.  There were subtle hints and clever moments that just placed that intelligent smile on your face.  Troy did the same even threw in a couple "fun" CGI moments for everyone to share, but sadly that was it.If you could turn the sound off on your television or surround sound and watch this film, you probably will experience a better picture than I did.  From the opening scene until the very anti-climactic moment in Troy, the hardest trouble that I had was the accents that accompanied our actors.  Brian Cox is one of the worst as I nearly found myself laughing in hysteria when he bellowed his first lines in a very un-Greek British accent.  This was followed by Orlando Bloom dawning a very unmasculine British accent coupled with Peter O'Toole looking very un-Trojan in his element.  If that wouldn't have been the tip of the ice cream, we were allowed to add sprinkles with the grunting force of Brad Pitt as our heroine/anti-heroine Achilles.  Taking moments from Rocky and Cobra, Pitt gives us his worst performance to date as a man given the strength of millions, but the emotions of a child.  It is sad to see Pitt butcher such an amazing character and never look back in suspicion.  This was not the role for him, and somebody (even the best boy) should have stepped out of his place to inform the Hollywood hitter that perhaps he was making a grave mistake.  Unfortunately, nobody came through and Troy was created and the power of Fight Club was thrown right out the window.  Corporate Hollywood had its field day in the Trojan sun.Another steaming issue that I had with this film was the pacing and timing of the overall picture.  Why did it take two hours to get to the most popular moment of the film?  Why did Petersen bog the viewers down with idle moments of passion and unnecessary character development when really we were most interested in learning about the infamous "Trojan Horse" and the "Achilles Heel" references?  I would hate to say it, but those were two of the reasons why I was very interested in seeing this film.  I wanted to see Petersen's portrayal of this historical moment, but instead what I discovered was that choppy editing left too much on the sandy desert floor.  It felt, at least to me, that the ending was very rushed and very underdeveloped.  The ending seemed cheaper to me, and without giving anything away, almost out of the precedent set forth by the beginning of the film.  I think Petersen knew that he had run out of time and the budget was already too big, so the ending was forced to suffer.  This ultimately hurt the film more than helped it giving it that sensation of a two-week science project done the night before.  I felt sorry for those involved with this droopy ending.To be honest, you had a very powerful story here that failed due to corporate Hollywood deciding to cast big names to fill the parts and place more emphasis on who was going to get the most screen time instead of story.  The actors hurt this film more than most will imagine because they just never fully represented the power of Homer's work.  I would have never imagined seeing Brad Pitt fighting along in Greek/Trojan times, and even after seeing this film I still cannot.  Brian Cox, normally fascinating in every film he does, just fell flat on his face in this film with the yelping of British words during this era.  It didn't fit causing the epic to quickly transform into nothing for that another summer blockbuster.  The story didn't help much either, forcing us to desperately want to get back into our High School Latin class to relive the truth of the story one last time.SEMPER UBI SUB UBI!!!Grade: *** out of *****
summary: Careful boy, my mercy has limits.

reviewText: Troy is neither a faithful retelling of the Iliad, the epic Homeric poem it was inspired by, nor a Hollywood computer generated sword and sandal film hoping to cash in on the popularity of Gladiator. Instead Troy is the timeless story of people caught up by the ravages of war.The film begins at the end of a long war of unification by Mycenaean King Agamemnon (Brian Cox) of the proto-Greek city-states. In history the Mycenaeans were recent barbarian conquerors of Greece, and we get a hint of this especially in Cox's portrayal of Agamemnon. He is in turns arrogant, playful and greedy. The only Mycenaean king we see who is tries to rule well is Odysseus (Sean Bean).From the battle scene at the beginning of the film, it is Achilles (Brad Pitt) who grabs your attention. He is brooding, arrogant and thinks his immortality will be to be known as the greatest warrior in history. This is an interesting contrast to Trojan Prince Hector (Eric Bana). Hector is a veteran professional soldier, not a warrior. He wants nothing more but to end the war, and protect his people.The war in which he finds this immortality is started with Prince of Troy Paris (Orlando Bloom) encourages Queen Helen of Sparta (Diane Kruger) to run off with him, at the end of a treaty negotiation with her husband Menelaus (Brendan Gleeson). Both come across as sympathetic, guilt ridden and fully aware of the disaster they have caused.Menelaus quickly goes to Agamemnon, his brother, for help to get Helen back. Agamemnon is more interested in taking Troy, a city astride the Dardanelle's (close to Gallipoli), and blocking his access to wheat grown in what is now the Ukraine.The fight scenes take place the beach in front of the city, and eventually inside it. Most of them are done with CGI, though at times the movie can look like an animation from the PC game Age of Empires. But on the ground, they are bloody and full of frenetic energy. Pitt's Achilles fights ability, speed and strength. His cold blue-eyed stare says more then any words he may speak during the film.When he does talk, for most of the film it is to noble slave girl Briseis (Rose Byrne). Around her he visibly softens (and hardens again, but that comes later on). Until Hector kills his cousin Patroclus, in his armour, Achilles is all set to take Briseis, and sail away forever.Director Wolfgang Petersen made his name with the 1981 German film Das Boot (the Boat). Troy has a similar somber feel to it. Rather then filling his movie with typecast heroes and villains, his characters become people who are dealing with circumstances beyond their control. War is the only evil in Troy, and the only people we see are its victims.
summary: A Sword and Sandal Metaphor for the War on Terror

reviewText: In order to avoid killing off their hero and Orlando Bloom, the writers of this movie completely rerouted the story!  Achilles was never in the Trojan horse, and yet we see him pop right out!  There is no secret passageway for a happy ending, yet all our favorite characters escape to freedom.  Achilles never returns Hector's body, but to make us like his character, he must show this compassion.But let's put all that aside- how about the acting?  Now, I'm a big fan of Orlando Bloom but I must say that in this movie he came off as effeminate!  And Helen wasn't really stunning- her face would never launch 1,000 ships.  Maybe 2.  Brad Pitt was really fantastic, but the other actors didn't impress me all that much.If you're a Greek mythology buff, you will be sorely disappointed.  For everyone else, it's enjoyable if you look past its striking flaws.
summary: Only okay- they changed the story!

reviewText: The story of the incomparable (to mortals anyway) Greek beauty Helen, the siege of Troy, and the "Trojan" Horse is the stuff of epic legend, told and retold orally and in prose over thousands of years. Homer's two poems, The Illiad and The Odyssey, are perhaps the most famous of these retellings. Recent attempts to adapt these and other works to film usually fall short for one reason or another, and director Wolfgang Petersen's most recent effort, Troy, unfortunately is no exception.After a brief graphic introduction and voice-over (by Odysseus, played by Sean Bean), Agamemnon (Brian Cox) and Achilles (Brad Pitt) are brought to the fore; the former, a power-hungry and ruthless King, and the latter a powerful warrior in Agamemnon's army seemingly sick of war yet fascinated by his own glory. After Achilles easily dispatches the Thessalyian champion and winning the war, the scene shifts to Sparta, home of Agamemnon's brother Menelaus (Brendan Gleeson), where a peace treaty is being signed with Troy, a powerful city-state across the Aegean in current in Asia Minor. Representing Troy are Princes Hector (Eric Bana) and Paris (Orlando Bloom) - during the celebration Paris slips away to sleep with Menelaus' wife Helen (Diane Kruger).Helen has little love for Menelaus and the two lovers decide to steal away on Paris' ship bound for Troy the next day. Menelaus, slightly perturbed, visits Agamemnon to ask his brother to support him in going to war with Troy, for Menelaus' honor if nothing else. Agamemnon, seeing the advantages of a fallen Troy and the growth of his own empire, gleefully accepts, and enlists Odysseus' help in bringing the disinterested Achilles to his cause. The Trojans accept Helen, but soon realize that war is on its way: a thousand Greek ships appear over the horizon.Troy can be many things to many people, but most would be disappointed in one way or another. Those looking for a visual realization of Homer's epic poems will see that very little made it to the screen, nor is the movie completely based on just Homer. The Trojan Horse itself isn't even in The Illiad. While some of the characters are highly religious, the godly figures of Greek mythology never make an appearance (unlike the stories). According to legend, the siege lasted some ten years - in the movie, it didn't even last two weeks. Varying characters die when they shouldn't, and live when they should have died.Many of the motivations, subterfuges, and plots by characters are either simplified or disregarded for the movie. Achilles' motivation seems to be an attempt to reach ever-higher pillars of fame and glory, until his encounter with the Priestess of Apollo (and thereafter slave) Briseis (Rose Byrne), at which point he barely wants to do anything. Agamemnon is a bloodthirsty tyrant, Menelaus a heartless killer, and Paris a cowardly sop. Hector is the wonderfully portrayed reluctant defender of Troy with the specter of death hanging over him, while Odysseus is the great survivor, thinker, and trickster. The latter two essentially are the only likeable characters throughout.Characters continually tell each other how this will be a war that will go down in history and be the stuff of legends, but their actions (except for Achilles going in the first place) disagree. The source material contains all these great characters and motivations, yet they mostly remain wooden and forgotten.For a movie that stretches beyond two and a half hours, Troy is barely even a movie about battles. There is one major battle, two minor ones, and really five duels, one lasting all of about five seconds. While the legends concentrate on the heroic deeds of warriors and individualistic combat, you see very little of that outside of the duels, and sometimes not even then. While the spectacle of the one singular immense battle is amazing, it very nearly serves little purpose except to kill two characters and show that Agamemnon wasn't a very good general - and maybe that he really did need Achilles (who sat it out). The other battles aren't really battles at all, just one side getting beat up at the expense of the other.Which is not to say the battles aren't impressive - the duels and struggles are wonderfully filmed and occasionally gory. Yes, the landing sequence does remind the viewer of Omaha Beach ala Saving Private Ryan, and there's a little too much shaky-cam going on. Hector vs. Achilles, however, is simply fantastic.Petersen, who directed the greatest submarine film of all time, Das Boot, the schmaltzy Air Force One, and the drowning tour de force The Perfect Storm, is off and on in Troy. Some scenes are wonderfully crafted, others are just sloppy. The battle sequences look great, the scenes where he cuts to character reactions seem really off. The script is weak in parts, as is the acting (Orlando Bloom in particular) - James Horner's quickly rushed score is horrific. Nice to see such a great ensemble cast (including Julie Christie, Peter O'Toole, Nigel Terry, Trevor Eve, Saffron Burrows and Julian Glover).It's hard to recommend Troy, because it's so uneven. Aside from the few shots of the naked flanks of a muscular, tanned Brad Pitt, even the screaming throngs of women may be disappointed. When you consider that the movie could have been so much better, if they had kept the characters and motivations a little more down to earth, if they had made the siege an epic struggle rather than a big battle and a wooden horse, than Troy could have been a much better movie. As it stands currently it's merely passable.

reviewText: "Troy" doesn't pretend to be an accurate depiction of the Homeric epic poem but states in its credits that it is merely "inspired by" "The Iliad." That kept in mind, this massive film has spectacle and beauty, and the feel and often the look of the great sword and sandal epics of the 1950s. Filmed in Mexico and Malta, the cinematography is a feast for the eyes, and there is wonderful detail in some of the lavish costuming and art direction. The romantic aspects of the story have been thankfully minimized, and the film focuses on the courage and heroism, as well as the lust for power and carnage of war.There are many excellent performances throughout, and I especially enjoy Eric Bana as Hector, and Sean Bean as Odysseus. Orlando Bloom is good as Paris, as are Peter O'Toole as Priam, Brendan Gleeson as Menelaus, Brian Cox as Agamemnon, Rose Byrne as Briseis, Vincent Regan as Eudorus, and a short but lovely appearance by Julie Christie as Achilles' mother, Thetis. Brad Pitt looks like a golden god and is believable as the larger than life Achilles, and is fantastic in the fight scenes. The brilliantly choreographed battle between Achilles and Hector is memorable, and has to be one of the best mano a mano action sequences in film history.Some of the loveliest music written today is for film, and James Horner has outdone himself in "Troy," with the gorgeous song "Remember Me," sung by Josh Groban, and the atmospheric voices of Tanja Tzarovska and Desislava Stefanova woven throughout the score. Wolfgang Peterson's sweeping direction, the cinematography of Paul Bond and Roger Pratt, and the script by David Benioff make this satisfying, and often riveting viewing, and it's a film that should be seen multiple times to fully appreciate. Total running time is 163 minutes.
summary: A Timeless Epic of Great Heroism and Beauty

reviewText: I admire the courage of Wolfgang Petersen. Making "Troy" was bound to be controversial. The big question was how much of Homers work do you actually use? Petersen has never shied away from diffcult films, think about Das Boot - in my opinion the best submarine film ever made. Troy was doubtless his greatest challenge.The result was a compromise of sorts. The history of the Trojan war will likely never be fully known. The work of Schliemann is certainly controversial still and no where near universally accepted my modern historians.Petersen, I think did the right thing by keeping the gods directly out of it, other than the characters beliefs and fealties or contempt to or for the gods. Petersen tried to make a historical film based on one version of the history of Troy and probably the most interesting of the interpretations.Like many here I have read and enjoyed the classics of Homer, and have read several translations of both works. Petersen seemed to take some of the most realsitic sounding elements and wove them into an epic film.Casting was inspired and brilliant despite my initial skepticism about Pitt's role as Achilles I was pleasantly suprised at his skill in bringing the character to life.The best in my opinion was Eric Bana's potrayal of Hector. I had always beleived Hector to be the honorable hero that this film brought to the part and from now on I will never again be able to read The Iliad without picturing Bana as Hector. Bravo!As always Peter O'Toole brings class and sophistication to any role and he brought King Priam to life for me. That scene in the tent with Achilles was in my opinion was an Acadamy Award grade performance.I thought Sean Bean played too much the nice guy as Odysseus, but overall I would like to see him in a Wolfgang Petersen version of The Odyssey. Brian Cox nearly stole the show as Agamemnon and performed equally to Pitt's Achilles.The women were all marvelous especially Saffron Burrows as Andromache and Rose Byrne playing Briseis.Writing was excellent and there are way too many excellent lines to mention but one of my favorites was the scene with Agamemnon and Achilles:Agamemnon: A great victory was won today, but that victory  was not yours. Kings do not kneel to Achilles. Kings do not pay homage to Achilles.Achilles: Perhaps the kings were too far behind to see: the soldiers won the battle.Agamemnon: History remembers KINGS, not soldiers! Tomorrow we'll batter down the gates of Troy. I'll build monuments for victory on every island of Greece. I'll carve Agamemnon in the stones.Achilles: Be careful King of kings. First you need the victory.Visual effects were top grade and I was surprised to see how much the crew actually built of the sets. yes they used a lot of CGI but they built a lot and it all looked great especially the horse. If the Trojan Horse actually ever existed I am sure it looked much like the horse built by the film crew.I bought the DVD and plan to watch it many more times.Highly recommended.

reviewText: This is a film adaptation of the classic The Iliad by Homer and it's loosely based on this work. They decided to give it a more historical setting and took out most of the references to the Gods exception in just a few references. I read they wanted to keep it out of the realm of fantasy and this was the reason for the removal of the Gods, but I felt that they were very important to the story and this would have been different if they would have included them.But that aside the movie is well done. They don't vary from the plot enough to change the story significantly. The actors in this film are all very good and Orlando Bloom played Paris to a "T". He played the version of  Paris as a weak, facillating character very well that I sometimes forget he can be otherwise. Eric Bana did a good job as Hector and I feel that so far this is his best. Pitt, I'll admit, is lacking a bit for me as Achilles, but he does his best.The action scenes are good, the dialogue isn't too bad and the pace of the story is done just right. This is a fun movie to watch, but the book is better.

reviewText: I had anticipated this film for months (ever since those pesky pop up ads with images and trailer links started popping up on me every time I went to certain websites! UGH!). I finally got to see it. My verdict: Good, not Great.However, what it did do is spur me on to rent some of Brad Pitt's other movies. WOW. I just moved him from my eye-candy list to my outstanding actors list. GREAT!I digress---Pitt actually does ok in Troy. Unfortunately this film had so much more potential. I do not think we will be hearing much about Troy come Oscar time (not in the major categories at least). That's a shame because, as far as source material, what could be better?Eric Bana is spectacular. Peter O'Toole is amazing. Orly--well he does well enough but quite honestly some of those wierd facial expressions irritate. He's young though--he has potential.I didn't think much of any of the women in this movie. The actress who played Helen was especially flat. Hector's wife was o.k. and Achilles love interest was good. The story was ok. The battle scences were exceptionally well done (and get my highest nod). The score was ok.I guess that about sums it up. It was OK. I am spoiled by LOTR as Peter Jackson (THE MASTER) just blew me away. Troy just never really gets there emotionally for you. You watch the characters but you don't really feel for them with a few notable exceptions: Hektor and Achilles fight scence was superb and Priam and Achille's conversation had me in tears I was so touched. Yet overall my emotional level remained pretty constant.I do not think this movie can really be compared with Braveheart or Gladiator but its a good movie and worth a cinema visit to see it on the big screen. I give it four stars for the fact that it did hold my attention and the two scences above were outstanding enough that it merits a higher rating.
summary: Good movie that doesn't quite live up to epic but entertains

reviewText: I like this movie a lot. In fact, I come close to loving it. The battle scenes between the Greeks and the Trojans were super-everything from the throwing of spears to the swinging of swords to the firing of arrows to the catapulting of fireball rocks. Oh and there was plenty of blood, too(Niiiiccccceee!)Blood flying everywhere-in pints! Wicked. Achilles, by the way, was my favorite character. Brad Pitt did him superbly and Hector was in close second place, as Eric Bana played him like a dream and he showed that just as Achilles was the Greek of all Greeks, Hector was the Trojan of all  Trojans. All of this is true as far as I'm concerned. On top of that, Helen was wicked sexy and more beautiful than any woman I've seen in any movie, and King Priam was  very brave for someone who did little fighting. However, despite that, and the fact that the Trojan Horse was built very well, I did not like Paris very much. He was a coward and a wimp. But other than that, this movie rocks!
summary: A very cool Trojan War movie! Oh, and Achilles rules!

reviewText: After watching "Troy" last night, I had mixed feelings at best.  I had been looking forward to this latest adaptation of Homer's great epic for the last couple of years.  "The Iliad" has been my favorite book since I was a kid - I've read several translations over the years, and have also read Homer's "The Odyssey", Virgil's "The Aeneid", Quintus of Smyrna's "The Fall of Troy", Aeschylus' "Agamemnon", "The Libation Bearers" and "The Euminides", Sophocles' "Ajax", and Euripides' "Iphigenia in Aulis", "Hecuba", "The Trojan Women" and "Andromache" for good measure.  These books (along with the now-lost "Cypria", "Ileupersis", the "Little Iliad" and the "Nostoi" of which we only have fragments) provide the complete back-story to the decade-long Trojan War.  Finally getting to see a big screen adaptation (with Brad Pitt as Achilles and Aussie hunk Eric Bana as Hector, no less) was certainly an exciting prospect.  The last big screen adaptation of "The Iliad" was made in the 1956 ("Helen of Troy") and centred on the characters of Paris and Helen, beautifully portrayed by Jacques Sernas and Rosanna Podesta.  The more recent 2003 TV mini-series adaptation, likewise called "Helen of Troy", also focused on Paris and Helen.  Both were serviceable, though I disliked the latter version for the number of unforgivable liberties it took with the story of the Trojan War, like having a BALD Vin Diesel wannabe portray a savage, cowardly and irredeemable Achilles.  Unfortunately, "Troy" is typical Hollywood - all pomp and circumstance, blood and gore, with little heart or emotional resonance.  "Troy" is certainly mixed bag.  It is entertaining - there are enough blood and gore to satisfy the blokes and plenty of hunky male flesh to satisfy the ladies.  The battle scenes are fantastic, and the climatic fight scene between Brad Pitt's Achilles and Eric Bana's Hector is heart-stopping stuff.  If you haven't read Homer, you would probably enjoy it.  But if you are a Homer fan, you would probably squirm at the liberties taken with Homer's great epic.  And now, for my gripes.  There are spoilers ahead, so do not read further if you do not want to know any major plot points in the movie.1. One of my biggest gripes is the tampering done with Homer's sublime scene in which King Priam of Troy begs Achilles for the body of his son, Prince Hector.  In Homer's original, King Priam softens Achilles' heart by comparing himself to Achilles' father, King Peleus of Phtia.  Both were once great and noble warriors - both are now old and defenseless men who rely on their sons for love, hope, security and protection.  But while King Peleus still has hope that Achilles will return from war one day, King Priam is devoid of hope since his most beloved son and heir is dead.  And King Priam has endured what no other man has ever done - kissed the hands of the man who killed so many of his sons.  In Homer, it was this appeal to Achilles' feelings for his own father that softens the great warrior's heart.  In "Troy" however, Achilles' father is supposedly long dead by then, which renders that whole pivotal scene senseless.2. The Trojan War was supposed to have lasted for TEN long gruelling years.  Homer's epic actually covers only several weeks during the ninth year of the war.  "The Iliad" ends with Hector's funeral, and it is actually other works like "The Odyssey", "The Aeneid" and "The Fall of Troy" that go on to provide the details of how Troy lost the war.  And yet "Troy" resolved the entire war in a matter of days.3.  Prince Paris gives the "Sword of Troy" to the first Trojan refugee he finds?  He entrusts the future hope for the Trojan race to an unknown stranger?  In the ancient epics, far from being an anonymous refugee, Aeneas is Troy's second best warrior.  It is he who fights at the forefront of war with Hector most of the time.  It is he who would go on to revive the lot of Trojans by setting up a new colony for the refugees that would later become Rome.4.  In the ancient epics, Patroclus and Achilles grew up together (Patroclus is actually the ELDER cousin) - they were inseparable and were the best of friends.  They were probably even lovers (Homer was rather coy about this although the hints are all over the place, and being bisexual was not unusual amongst Greek warriors), which was why the full wrath of Achilles was only unleashed when Hector killed Patroclus.  Patroclus pretended to be Achilles in a heroic and desperate bid to fool the Trojans into retreating from the burning Greek ships.  In "Troy", Patroclus was a naive younger cousin who died because he foolishly disobeyed orders.  Short of being a completely unmitigated savage, there would have been no reason for Achilles to behave like a beast in desecrating Hector's body.5.  Where is Cassandra and her dire warnings about Greeks bearing gifts?  Where is Queen Hecuba?6.  The Agamemnon in "Troy" is a caricature - the ultimate cruel, corrupt and amoral politician.  There is no hint of that most painful of sacrifices that Agamemnon has to make to embark on his war - that very sacrifice that turned him from being merely a greedy and ambitious politician to being such a deadly and almost insane enemy to all things Trojan.  The sacrifice of Iphigenia, seen so powerfully in 2003's "Helen of Troy", should have been in this movie.  As should have been Agamemnon's ultimate fate in the hands of HIS OWN WIFE, not Briseis.The one bright spot in "Troy" is Sean Bean's Odysseus.  He's the one character that seems most consistent with how Homer himself would have wanted him portrayed.  Sigh ... if I could have my wish, I would take the best elements of all three versions of the Trojan War made so far ("Helen of Troy" 1956, "Helen of Troy" 2003 and "Troy" 2004) and combine them into one movie.  By all means, watch this movie if you like the swords and sandals genre.  But don't go in expecting a faithful adaptation of "The Iliad".

reviewText: Why would I want to see the director's cut to a movie that was, well, cliched and sweaty?  I suppose so I could hear the director's commentary on how long Brad Pitt spent oiling up his arms so they could shine in every scene?  Maybe so I can see the one character I thought three-dimensional die again.  Or maybe it's so I can see the gag reel which probably features the actors laughing at their own dialogue.  Either way, I'm not interested in the pre-production process that decided to dismiss the importance of the gods in this story, throw in contemporary dialogue, and (I thought this was impossible) parody ancient Greek art.  Seems like a waste of time.

reviewText: Blu-Ray review.  If you are reading this for the DVD copy, this information may not be accurate.Film:  4/5, Image Quality:  5/5, Audio Quality:  4.5/5, Extras:  3/5, Overall:  4/5Quality:This Blu-Ray is like a gift from the gods.  The picture quality is supremely colorful, vibrant, clean, and has excellent sharpness and detail.  Sound quality is uncompressed, and it is really clear and clean, but I did have to turn the volume up quite a bit more than usual; it seems rather subdued.  Some parts also seemed a bit muffled; possibly due to source issues from reinserted footage.This Blu-Ray disc presents the extended Director's Cut, which is nearly 200 minutes long and contains a lot of interesting new footage that's perfectly interwoven in the movie itself.  The disc also contains a number of featurettes and a trailer.Film:Personally, I am not familiar with the original story for the battle of Troy, so I can't comment on how historically/mythically/culturally accurate this movie really is.  Whether it's fully embellished or not, it is a rather fun and timeless story; it is only appropriate that Hollywood should someday film it with such a high production cost and a full list of A-list actors.This is such a film; a slick and stylish production with plenty of large-scale set-pieces, exotic-looking locations, huge battles and fight scenes, ambitious CGI effects, and a smidgeon of classic romance.  The talents of Brad Pitt, Eric Bana, Orlando Bloom, Sean Bean, and even Peter O'Toole are all dispensed here.  Watching "Troy" is about as rewarding of an experience as the long list of other Hollywood epics (such as "Jason and the Argonauts," or "300"), for better or for worse.The best part about this film is that it is tremendously entertaining.  Whether watching the original two-hour theatrical cut or the rather sublime three-hour director's cut, the film is tightly paced and hardly ever dull.  Battle scenes are spectacular and often times bloody.  Individual fight scenes are pretty swell too.  The CGI work is a little fake-looking, but still well-realized and quite slick to look at.  Outside of the battles, the film is quite pretty to look at, with so many unique settings and solid camera work.The most negative aspects about this film would likely be reserved for the pickiest of viewers.  Despite the film's quality production, it is not even comparable to the most highly-rated epics in this genre; movies like "Gladiator" and "Braveheart" can easily out-match "Troy." After all, "Troy" does not have the same quality writing and acting, much less the same thematic prowess or emotional power.  It is certainly not as immersive, deep, or insightful.In the end, "Troy" is a polished and entertaining film.  It comes recommended to most casual audiences, but those looking for full artistic valor can do better.4/5 (entertainment:  4/5, story:  4/5, film:  4/5)
summary: "Let them say that I walked with giants."

reviewText: I am a mythology fan, and I was really looking forward to this movie.  I became immediately alarmed at the slow beginning, and while I was entertained for the majority of the movie, something wasn't quite right and I didn't know what it was until the end.  WHERE was the MEAT of the STORY?  Sure, it was "explained" nicely, but I felt incredibly ripped off from the minimal portrayal of Helen of Troy and the CRITICAL role she played.  Also, as another reviewer mentioned, there are no gods in this film... they are mentioned and briefly shown in statues, but there are no live characters-- dissapointing.That aside, there was some *excellent* battle scenes that I've been hungry for in a non-LOTR setting for a change.  Also, there was some really good acting from the supporting roles which really carried this film through.I normally would avoid comparing this to similiar films of this vein, however, the background music is so similar to that of Gladiator (which can take the Pepsi Challenge with this movie any ol' day of the week) I found myself reflecting back on Gladiator and feeling that Troy was a lesser film.  Much to my delight, some of the actors from Braveheart play important lead roles in Troy, so again, I felt myself yearning for strength in story that Braveheart had.

reviewText: *** This comment may contain spoilers ***When I first saw the preview, I thought "What a fantastic idea!" movies about Ancient Greece seemed rare to me (not being a fanatic, or knowing of the older movies)I knew once the movie was over that it was very poor... and it took me a few more viewings to realize how horrible it was.First off, the music is all middle-eastern sounding. I realize Troy is in western Asia-ish (like around ancient Pergamum and such) and such, but come one, this music sounded like a day in the deserts of Arabia. More suited for Kingdom of Heaven or Hidalgo.Historical accuracy?  You'd find a fair share more in something like Gladiator or Kingdom of Heaven (not to bash the films, simply pointing out that they aren't very accurate). Agammemnon and Menelaus are portrayed as fat greedy villains interested only in themselves, the Trojans portrayed as noblemen and upright in every way (even Paris, who in mythology, was sly as a fox), and Achilles as a moody drama queen! He's stubborn and arrogant and stuck-up and very very rude, like when he told that poor boy in Thessalonica, "That's why no one will remember your name" when the boy said he was afraid of the Thessalonican warrior sent to fight Achilles.The battle which was supposed to be 10 years, seemed to last less than a month, with most of that time being the 12 days they gave peace for Hector's death! In the entire movie, none of the characters change in appearance---Peter O'Toole's Priam looks on the verge of death, without any change, Agammemnon doesn't gray, no one changes in what is supposed to be 10 years, and the way the movie passes makes it seem like each passing day is just that; one passing day. Agammemnon and Menelaus survive in mythology, yet both die in this movie, probably because they were the "bad guys" in the film.This is a big one: Mythology. This movie seems to spit in the face of mythology, use Homer's book pages as toilet paper, and then throw up venom on the sheer "coolness" of the legend of Troy. The legend of Achilles being immortal and his only weakness being his heel is sneered at, when Paris shoots Achilles through the heel, we think "WOW! the legend! His heel is his only weak spot!" hence the term "Achilles Heel" meaning our greatest weakness...Then Achilles gets shot five times in the chest. So to the average viewer, who knows nothing about Achilles's legend, what do you think kills Achilles, a shot in the heel, or five shots in the chest?That plus the callous way in which the director--through characters like Hector and Achilles and such--seem to treat the Gods like crap, and doesn't portray their influence at all, as opposed to say "Alexander", which gives the Gods a light, dubious touch, such as showing hints of Zeus watching over him (the Eagle). The Trojans constantly claim the Gods are on their side, and the pompous way in which they say it seems to make you envision the director going "Pfft, what idiots! believing in the Gods of their time, HAH! Jesus Christ our lord and savior is the only God and THEY should've known that! So they die for their heresy! DIE DIE DIE!"Another big problem is something that also messed up the game Warcraft III. It is TOO HERO-BASED. In the movie, so much emphasis is placed on heroes like Achilles and Hector, that the armies pretty much play absolutely no role at all in the movie! It doesn't matter that the Greeks outnumber the Trojans 2 or 3 to 1, they absolutely can't win without Achilles!!! It doesn't matter that the Trojans are defended by epic walls and the best archers in the world, they can't win without Hector!!!All in all, a very poor put-together movie, with a kind of stubborn negative and childish mentality towards the ways, beliefs, and customs of the times, pretty much re-writing the legend of Troy to make it more marketable to audiences who want to gawk at Brad Pitt naked (yes, he's naked several times for no real reason) and the amount of men they can cram into one shot. The acting is wooden, and hearing Achilles whine and sass like a snotty teenage girl just irritates.  The characters are portrayed all wrong, the Gods and the Myths aren't just ignored---they're subtly cursed and treaded and stomped in the mud.The legend was torn open, the parts the director liked picked apart, and made more Hollywood-friendly for the money.
summary: Terrible film.. only given a star because it looks like it cost some money

reviewText: I've given up trying to rationalize Hollywood's MO of changing classics to their own views on what they percieve audiences will like - and I can't understand why they changed the Iliad the way they did ... other than to try and keep a sympathic audience who couldn't bear to see the much more tragic ending than the one in the film. The film's changes make for a more "neat and tidy" resolution - but more empty in the themes Homer was trying (at least I think) to express.The Iliad's gut wrenching tragedy and drama is what has kept it alive for 2700+ years. Though definitely a feast for the eyes - this film left my mind stirring - "all this for what?"(Spoilers - Warning)The characters I felt the most were Hector and Priam. Pitt's Achillies was 90% there - but a bit too much sulking and brooding. His sudden sympathetic turn at the end also contrasted to sharply and quickly with his more hardened and faithful Achillies rendering through most of the film.Agamemnon - over the top; guess Hollywood felt they needed a real "badie," and had to give the audience the standard "bad guy gets it in the end" ending, having one of the heroines kill him.Orlando Bloom - Paris the "ueberwimp"And then there's the whitewashed ending with everyone escaping Troy (Paris, Helen, Hector's wife and baby).The film is essentially a new story, very loosely based on classic characters. Well filmed though, and very good soundtrack.
summary: Evokes similar emotions as The Iliad - but why change things?

reviewText: Homer's "The Illiad" is one of literature's greatest war stories.  It begins with a contest among the gods, which the Trojan prince Paris (played by Orlando Bloom in the film) is chosen to decide.  The three goddesses each promise him something if he selects them, and Aphrodite, the goddess of Love, makes him an offer he can't refuse: Queen Helen of Sparta (Diane Kruger), the most beautiful woman in the Aegean.  So Paris kidnaps Helen, which prompts her husband Menelaus (Brendan Gleeson) to call upon the other Greek kings who opted for her hand in marriage.  You see, when nearly every Greek king wanted to marry Helen, including Agammemnon (Brian Cox), and Odyseus (Sean Bean), Odyseus came up with a plan: there would be a kind of trial to win Helen, and then the losers would band together against any enemy if said enemy ever tried to steal Helen from the winner.  Well, the kings followed the plan, and they sailed to Troy in order to get her back.  A 10-year war followed, with the main figures being Achilles (Brad Pitt) on the side of the Greeks, and Hector (Eric Bana) on the side of the Trojans.Ok, for the most part, that did not happen in the movie.  I'm not sure if it was the writer or the director, Wolfgang Peterson, who chose to do this, but the gods, who played a pivotal role in the Trojan War, were all but eliminated from the story.  Anyway, the movie gets started as Menelaus is treating his guests, the Trojan princes Hector and Paris, to a peace dinner.  Troy is one of the few, and definitely the most powerful, states that is not under Greek rule, which angers Menelaus' brother Agammemnon, who wants to rule the Aegean Sea.  Throughout this stay, Paris and Helen have been having an affair, and Paris convinces her to come home with him, and she consents.  This angers Menelaus so much that he goes to his brother, asking for help in "getting her back".  Agammemnon uses this as an excuse to go to war with Troy, and he assembles an army of 50,000 Greeks to fight Troy.  Odyseus and Achilles are two of the leaders enlisted to fight, but Agammemnon is weary of Achilles, for the two detest each other.  When Agammemnon steals one of Achilles' girls that he captured, Achilles decides to stop fighting and watch the Greeks get slaughtered.  It takes the death of his cousin Patroclus (Garrett Hedlund) by Hector to get him back into the war.I have to say that I liked this movie.  It was very riveting and very entertaining.  However, since I have such an extensive knowledge of Greek Mythology, I noticed many discrepancies that bugged me a little bit.  It mainly had to do with the deaths; some people died before they were supposed to, while others died after.  Also, some of the characters' motives were obscured.  I'm not completely sure about this, but I think the whole thing about Agammemnon being some war-hungry was a crack at President George W. Bush and the war in Iraq.  Agamemmnon was a pig, but he went to war for Helen, not land.Oh well, what are you going to do.  Achilles, Hector, and Odyseus were right on the mark.  The actors who played them did very good jobs playing them, and their attributes and morals were not obscured.  I did think that Odyseus was a bit underused, and he kind of sold himself short at the end, but it kind of set things up for The Odysey, Homer's other great epic, though I doubt it will be made with this crew.  They also set up Virgil's The Aeneid, as Paris handed the Sword of Troy over to Aeneis (Frankie Fitzgerald) in order to find a new home.My last word: go see this movie.  You will have a good time.  But if you are a Greek myth fan like myself, try not to pay too much attention to the "liberties" that were taken.
summary: Good Movie, But Too Many "Liberties" Were Taken

reviewText: I saw an early screening of the movie last night, and was quite impressed with Wolfgang Peterson's adaptation of an excellent and timeless story.For those who know little or nothing about the background of the story, they will probably not be convinced by some of the scenes (i.e. the abrupt endings/agreements in the middle of battles), but trust me...they are actually fairly accurate with the time they are portraying.Unlike some viewers, I thought Brad Pitt was perfectly cast as Achilles - he convinced me instantly that he was the arrogant, selfish, ultra-perfect warrior that Achilles was.  Actually, the real character of Achilles was much more brutal than how Peterson has him portrayed (in the killing of Hector, it actually took several days before Achilles would give up the body so it could be given a proper funeral...and he wasn't as sympathetic as Brad Pitt makes him out to be).It is true that Peterson does play around with the story and takes several liberties to fit into his vision of the film...but what director doesn't?  The important thing is that it embodies the heart of the story, and I think it does that perfectly.  The entire movie has that epic, greater-than-life quality that used to be present in the old Roman, "sword-and-sandal" films of the past...something the film Gladiator tried to do too, but while I loved that film also, I feel that Troy is much more accurate and much better executed overall. Especially when it came to the battle sequences...while Gladiator possessed none of the qualities of how the Romans actually fought (watch the movie Spartacus - it does a much better job), Troy succeeds in portraying how the ancient Greeks did.  And watching Achilles fight was simply breathtaking (excuse my bloodlust)!My greatest qualm, I guess, was the music.  I am not a huge fan of Horner...in my opinion, there are only a few times when he has been wholly inventive and original (Braveheart, Glory, and Legends of the Fall are probably the highlights of his career).  The majority of his music have been pathetic copies of either Braveheart (if you don't believe me, listen to Bicentennial Man) or some other previous work he's done.  There's nothing wrong with having a certain trademark sound to all your work - John Williams certainly stamps most of his music with a sound that is unique to him - but that is a huge difference from outright copying from yourself.  This time around, however, he didn't copy from himself...he just tried copying from Hans Zimmer's Gladiator soundtrack.  True, he doesn't outright copy from Zimmer, but it's obvious he's trying too hard to capture the magic of Gladiator's music...and he fails, I'm sorry to say.  It's not a bad soundtrack (I've heard a lot worse), but I wish it had been worthy of the movie.Okay, enough Horner-bashing (sorry to the many James Horner fans out there).  All in all, a great movie worthy of the great story it comes from.  If the story fails to convince the viewers as believable, that's because it does come from a legendary STORY that may or may not be true (the argument goes on and on).  I've studied both the facts and the legend, and am convinced that there was a Troy and a great battle at it...but as for the rest, well, who knows.I'll finally close with a reminder from the character of Odysseus...like him, when you watch the movie, you will walk with giants of legend.

reviewText: Even though its not the best take on Homer's the Iliad, its still immensely good. Especially when Brad Pitt plays Achillies, the greatest warrior in all the world's antiquity. Especially when its shown of how Agamemnon was a greedy, fat, strutting pig who had united the greeks just to line his pockets. Him and Achillies clash endlessly over everything, from Achillies having to fight battles against other nations hero's on down to him having to answer to Agamemnon. The part of where Paris seduces Helen whose miserable with her lush, womanizing husband Menelaius and decides to go to Troy with Paris is when the movie gains speed. That's when the Greeks mobilized their fleet, Achillies beating them to the beach and slaughtering at least a dozen or more Trojans, taking Apollo's temple, and desecrating it for good measure. In it he finds Breiseis, a Trojan noble woman who chose to be a preistess to Apollo who stirs him as the proverbial woman all men want but can never have. Agamemnon, just to spite and annoy Achillies takes Bresies as a slave making Achillies decide to sit out the next battle. This causes the Greeks to lose Ajax their second best fighter, Menelauis, and a sizable peice of their army. Agamemnon reluctantly gives Bresies to Achillies, who says she's know men like him her whole life and him repling that he was born this is what he is. That night she tries to slit his throat, only to have him make love to her in such a way she sleeps in his bed into morning. Achillies looks at her and considers something amazing for him, leaving Troy and the glory he'd have for all of time from fighting there. That night Achillies with Breises she asks him if he could leave this war, he replies could you leave Troy? His meaning if she could forget about her family, her culture, her country, her home he could forget about glory. Then his cousin is killed, and Achillies kills Hector dragging the body behind his chariot. That night Priam begs Achillies for Hector's body, discovering Briseis is alive and takes the two back to Troy. The Greeks desperate, play a tactic of subterfuge with a hollowed out horse and make it into Troy and begin the slaughter of Troy and its populace. Briseis is saved from Agamemnon by Achillies, only to be struck down by Paris and as he sits dying he looks at the only woman he ever truly loved with his very soul and says because of her he knew peace throughout a lifetime of war. Briseis escaping with the remaining Trojans to Mt. Ida pauses at the summit of the mountain looking at Achillies Funeral pyre a look of lose and being lost. A good movie, but read the Iliad first.

reviewText: I know a fair bit about Greek mythology and literature, and have an affection for it, but I still enjoyed this film, even though it took extreme liberties with the story AND characters.  The story the filmmakers chose to tell was exciting and the fight scenes were very good.  The sight of 1000 ships nearing Troy was terrific.Pros:  Brad Pitt and Eric Bana were terrific as Achilles and Hector, and they lead an extremely talented cast.  The cablecam shots were very well done, and I enjoyed the music a lot.Cons:  Orlando Bloom and the actress who played Helen were the weak links.  I never felt a chemistry between them, let alone a passion that would justify all those people dying, and Helen did not have a face that would launch a thousand ships.Extras include a Gallery of the Gods, about the Greek gods (though they were eliminated from the film), and three featurettes about special effects, battle sequences and sets.Worth seeing unless you're a purist -- then it would make you crazy.
summary: enjoyable for all but die-hard Greek purists

reviewText: Troy is a great fun date film filled with exterior panorama shots that harken to the old David Lean Lawrence of Arabia views, and of course, Brad Pitt, who is buff enough to give a girl the vapors. Lordy!However, for anyone who has ever read Homer, and has an iota of recognition of the Oddessey, the absence of the Greek gods is a major disappointment. Hollywood of course went for the love story between lesser characters to play up the roles of Orlando Bloom and Brad Pitt, and this was more an annoyance when actors with chops including Peter O'Toole were on screen. The Hollywood pretty boys looked decidedly underfed compared to the beefy Greek brothers of Sparta like Brian Cox, and at times this was an unexpected comical relief in fight scenes between the lithe Orlando Bloom as Paris and Agamemnon's kin.  It was not only laughable but cartoonish.The tender scenes between Hector and his wife and infant son were all but thrown out with the baby's bath water in this production as was the friendship between Achillies and Petrocles. Can't Hollywood just leave Homer alone if it wants to make a movie where a boy loves girl, girl runs away with the boy, and Greece goes after her with 50,000 extras. I enjoyed the spectacle, but missed the substance, however, Brad Pitt's pecs were a mighty rush of lust for the wide screen. Once Brad dropped his leather skirt, who cared!

reviewText: I was really looking forward to this movie. And boy was I really disappointed. I read parts of the Iliad in high school and admit I don't remember much about it, so my qualms with the film didn't involve any deviations from the epic by Homer. In fact I like how the movie tried, emphasis on "tried," to make the movie more realistic and left out direct involvement by the gods. The gods still played an important part in the film, but it was the human reaction to either the belief (King Priam of Troy) and disbelief (Hector and Achilles) in the gods and their will.My problems with the film stem mainly from the direction: it's horrible. Close-ups and slo-mo moments are meant to evoke drama but instead come off cheezy and unintentionally comical. The score, which is a bad GLADIATOR knock-off, is absolutely terrible. And the acting by a pumped-up Pitt was far from his best. Although the problems with his performance as the warrior Achilles as a conflicted philosopher trapped inside the worlds most efficient killer likely has a lot to do with the script. In true Hollywood form, TROY tries to give us clear-cut teams to root for and against.We know how the story ends, but TROY tries to make the audience not want it to happen. It fails. The story of TROY goes as thus: evil, power hungry Greek King Agamemnon uses his cuckolded brother Menelaus, who's wife Helen ran off with Prince Paris of Troy, as an excuse to launch the greatest Greek army in history to take control of Troy. The moody warrior Achilles, who hates Agamemnon, yet fights for him because he seeks glory and fame, governs the Greek army's morale with his own band of elite Greek warriors. The city of Troy is governed by old king Priam, who relies heavily on the council of his priests of Apollo, and his two sons: Hector and Paris. The younger Paris is a coward and selfish boy. Hector is the Trojan Achilles, but less conflicted. Hector believes in honor and country and family. In other words Hector is the "good" good guy to Achilles' "bad-boy" good guy. The two meet in an implausible yet climactic one-on-one battle that is the movie's high point.TROY tries and fails to combine aspects of BRAVEHEART & GLADIATOR with a lot of nude Brad Pitt scenes thrown for those into that sort of stuff. However, I went w/ 3 friends and all of us heckled the film throughout. Pretty much the entire theater agreed. We were all waiting for the film to just end so we could leave. Ultimately TROY is a film that takes itself too seriously and unintentionally turns melodrama into camp and has a few good fight scenes and some naked Brad butt thrown in for good measure.

reviewText: "May the gods keep the wolves in the hills and the women in our beds." Thus spoke Agamemnon at the start of this film, yet his words are strangely applicable to all men regardless of the age in which they were born. The same can be said of the epics of Homer. The working title of this film was The Illiad, but there are some major departures between the landmark of literature and the script from which the movie was made. Without the gods as characters, a great deal of the story loses its meaning. Furthermore, a "war, what is it good for?" angle has been introduced and instilled within the characters. In my humble opinion, such a stance concerning battles and death is strikingly misguided in relation to those who lived in the classical world. Sons and husbands dying was a daily occurrence, and many of the conversations in this movie are more reflective of twentieth century therapism than anything to do with the Greeks or Trojans.However, despite one's historical objections to the interjections made by the characters in the name of our times, Troy is a very entertaining movie. Its 2+ hours float by, and I can't recall a film that was so pretty. That sounds condescending but it isn't. Its colors are vivid, and the views engaging. It pleases regardless of how disjointed the narrative may be. As for Brad Pitt as Achilles, if you ask me, he is the best part of the movie. I know some people won't buy him in such a role, but I was quite impressed. He won his acting bona fides with me years ago in Kalifornia and stood out in Snatch as well. Additionally, I thought Sean Bean as Odysseus was outstanding.

reviewText: This film pretty much follows the story of Homers Iliad with very few exceptions and possible ending. However the few exceptions and ending is what makes this story work as a movie instead of a long poem. Stories being told may ways five different insights and there should be no conflict between the reader and viewer and both stories are real to the observer.For you that forgot the story and you that know the story well but have not seen this movie basically we are looking at a story that you may or may not have had an opportunity to sidestep in school but can never have a grasp on social history with out it. Some call it real and lost in antiquity. Others say that homer had a Good imagination. And others treat it as an allegory with a historical background.Brad Pitt who has played fickle people before is excellent in the part of Achilles and is sort of a heel. Nothing less was expected. It was the other actors that played their parts so well that you forgot you were watching the movie.-----------------------------------------------------Two Trojan princes are the guests of the Spartan ruler Menelaus (Brendan Gleeson). While Menelaus is preoccupied with other matters he leaves his wife, Helen of Sparta (Diane Kruger), to her own devises. The younger Trojan prince Paris (Orlando Bloom) is left alone to many times with Helen and decides against everyone else's better judgment to make her Helen of Troy and thus pilfers her from Menelaus.As a husband Menelaus is of course miffed. However his brother the Greek king Agamemnon (Brian Cox) sees this as an opportunity to absorb Troy into his territory. Natural this spawns a war in which Agamemnon recruits Achilles an extremely gifted and charmed warrior. Achilles goes to make a name for him self. He brings his cronies, and his cousin. Together they do many bold and callous things.I will not go into the details of the war as you either know or will soon know the details. However I will say that I thought that the Trojan horse was well and realistically designed. And you may want to pay attention to the background music as it is relevant to the film.

reviewText: This lavish war movie took us back 3,200 years ago to discover the truth about the legend of Achilles' heel. The scenes were similar to the primitive fight of our Civil War. The Trojan War was vast and destructive (as was the War Between the States in America); the Colonial Wars were just as bad. At least there was no scalping of prisoners or dead warriors as portrayed in Coyle's SAVAGE WILDERNESS. However, it was not an easy thing to see. Parts of the movie were shot in Mexico; the female vocal was performed by someone named Tanya. Johnny Mathis sang "Remember." The musical director was the marvelous James Horner of TITANTIC fame. War and horror movies depend on the orchestral mood-setting music, and this was no exception. At times, it was spectacular like the sunrise there in Mexico.Based on Homer's THE ILIAD, the saga is updated to 2004 sexual propensities. The nude scenes were not needed in such a movie, only lower the integrity of Homer's classic. The gladiators may have used primitive weapons, such as spears, shields, bows & arrows (they did play dirty using the fire arrows), and I like the nose guards on their helmets. The Trojans were dressed in gray, as they invaded. They loved a spectacle, sometimes fighting without shields. They trampled their own dead in retreat, with some revenge killings. At least, the dead were not left on the field (sand) for the vultures and given a burial pyre where they fell. There were many such death pyres similar to India's tradition. The final was an indoor flame for Hector, the real star of this saga, when the funeral games lasted twelve days.The fleet of ancient boats was quite spectacular. There was pandemonium in the streets (larger scale than in PIRATES OF PENZANCE in which Linda Ronstadt and Kevin Kline starred) as the fleet approached. There was mass slaughter inside the walls of the city and the fires turned it into a huge funeral pyre. Now, this is the film in which the Rock should have starred. Brad Pitt made a valiant effort. He looked silly, however, in a skirt; his outfits influenced this summer's skimpy styles for women. He looked like a woman with that hair style (bleached blonde to boot). He was a mean (though not lean) fighting machine.Jewelry was abundant on men with earrings and gold ornaments in their long hair. The women (except for Achilles mother) wore lavish jewels -- even the slave girl loved by Achilles (who turned out to be a real princess), was cousin of Hector. The old king, with his ugly teeth, played by Peter O'Toole was humanly portrayed as the father of two handsome sons: Hector married with a blue-eyed son (even Trojan babies suched their thumbs) and Paris who caused all this havoc by stealing the young wife, Helen, who just wanted a man she could grow old with. Her Greek husband was old enough to be her father. Women were used merely as chattal for sex and pro-creation, not much love involved. Achilles slept with women but he loved his male cousin. When the cousin gave his life (dressed as Achilles), a vendetta took place. Hector wasd a fool who thought he'd killed Achilles but revenge caused his death and his body was dragged thtough the desert tied to Achilles' chariot. The old king appealed for his son's body; consequently, we see the Trojan horse and the vermin who escaped to open the gates for a new, massive fleet of Greek warriors to wreck havoc.There were gorgeous horses in the seaside camp on the Trojan Beach. Thank God they freed the horses from the final inferno. The nudity was bad and totally unnecessary. There was a bevy of belly dancers at the feast in Sparta. At Phtia, there was a type of Stonehenge where Achilles practiced sword play with his cousin. His weakness was the sword through his heel as he could not walk, run, or fight back. As he cried before he died, I thought, "So, he was human after all, not just a killing monstrosity." He could find peace only in death.There was plunder as spoils of war. During the twelve-day reprieve, one of the Greek men was shown carving a stone horse with a sharp knife "for my son back home." I guess he got it, as there was a final victory with the Trojans being defeated. It does no good to be sorry 'after the fact.' We're all human, and humans make mistakes -- sometimes fatal. This extra-long movie (music kept it going) showed that even enemies can show respect. When Achilles "frees" the woman who loves him to return to her people (not caring how he hurts her), it parodies the old adage: "You Always Hurt The One You Love."
Title: N/A

reviewText: Well, now...aside from condensing a 10-year seige into a 2-week affair, I'd have to say that this film has some REALLY impressive elements.Brad Pitt--Hey, that fancy battle move is worth the whole price.  I thought Pitt did a wonderful job of conveying the "victory or death" credo of the Greek warrior.  He's a deliciously moody Achilles; and the nuances of soldiering philosophy "a conscience does not become a sword." is well carried off.  Pitt often gets less credit than he deserves, I think, because he makes it look too easy, and his performance in TROY is much more than adequate.  He creates an Achilles worthy of Homer.Olando Bloom and Eric Bana are equisitely matched at brothers Paris and Hector.  Eric Bana, especially, delivers a stirring performance of the antithesis of Achilles--a warrior with a conscience, a soldier with a reason to live (loving wife and family), a man who fights for his country, not personal glory.  Bana probably should have been considered for an Oscar.  Orlando's looks and the youthful impetuosity he gives Paris are nicely done.Great to see Sean Bean as Odysseus.  He was everything that planner should be--manipulative, winning.Peter O'Toole--Well, what can one say?  His performance as Priam is exquisite--especially as he pleads with Achilles for the body of his beloved son.  Unfortunately, Peter learned a long time ago that Oscar hates him...sad, isn't it?The weakest link is probably the portrayal of Helen.  She's the one character you'd probably want to know more about and yet she impresses the audience as a dishrag...it's a wonder Hector didn't feed her to Agamemnon for dinner just to be rid of her cow-eyed whinning.  I think maybe Paris might have helped him do it, actually.  She certainly was tiresome.  I think Helen just might have had a little more back bone than that--after all, she certainly wasn't ignorant of what the result of her actions would be.BUT...This film, for any flaws, has an "old-time-epic" feel about it that I don't think has been that well captured since BEN HUR.  The thousand ships, the Trojan Plains, the City Gates...it's all pure majesty.My family was mixed...My daughter, husband, and I liked it very much.  My son villified it for not being chapter and verse to THE ILLIAD.  But the bottom line is, it's worth a look...it'll make a rainy afternoon fun!
summary: The Trojan War in a Nutshell
Title: N/A

reviewText: Forget the fact that Greek mythology holds that the war was actually started by the gods up on Mount Olympus; forget the fact that Achilles' immortality but for his tendon (where the term "Achilles tendon" comes from) goes pretty much unmentioned; and forget the fact that Achilles actually died before the conquest of Troy and there were plenty of other exciting Greek warriors anyway. The reinventing of history by Hollywood isn't anything new. However, just because the plotline of a movie is inaccurate doesn't mean it has to be poorly done.Essentially, the plotline is that son of the Trojan king and queen, Paris (Orlando Bloom), falls in love with Menelaus (Brendan Gleeson), king of Sparta's, pretty wife, Helen (Diane Kruger). When Paris decides to smuggle Helen into the Trojan ship, the Greeks are furious because the two sides have just signed some sort of treaty. Thus, all of the warriors of Greece, who once signed a pledge to defend Helen, the most beautiful lady of the land, if any harm should befall her, are sent into battle. The Greeks bring out the big guns, most notably, the great warrior Achilles (Brad Pitt, in case you weren't aware) who agrees to fight despite his mother's (Julie Christie) prophecy that if he goes to Troy he will die. What ensues is basically a combination of intense battle scenes (but you're spoiled if you have seen Lord of the Rings) and some heady romantic scenes (Brad Pitt is naked in the very first shot), but other than that the whole affair is very shallow. If you know anything about the Iliad (and I'm not a Classics major) you will be groaning. The characters are skin-deep and hopelessly predictable.Brad Pitt does all right as a buff warrior, but there is no real room for him to scope out his acting ability. You will not be able to help rolling your eyes as you watch him show his "softer side" and teach his young protégé how to duel (and then of course experience the agonies of grief when he dies) as well as when he woos Briseis, a captured temple virgin (Rose Byrne), and then defends her as Troy falls. However, if you are looking for the wild and crazy rogue who played Tyler Durden in "Fight Club" then this is not the movie for you. German model Diane Kruger was a very safe choice for Helen-a typical blonde blue-eyed maiden with very little affect or attitude. Basically no one with any spunk or charisma would be an appropriate choice for Helen, because she is more of an object of desire than an actual human being. She played her role (which required minimal acting ability) well enough. Orlando Bloom was well-cast in his role as a pretty, cowardly sissy who spends his time being tortured and love-stricken and posturing for the ladies.Perhaps the worst aspect of this film was the screenplay! I have not encountered such terrible dialogue in a movie since "Titanic". Cliché lines such as `I will love you in this world and the next' are everywhere. An exchange between Helen and Paris which basically consists of: "You shouldn't be here!" "That's what you said last night and the night before that, etc." and then suddenly Helen's naked, caused the entire theater to burst out laughing! Actually the entire movie did! If the whole thing had been a spoof then it would have been fine, but as a serious movie, Troy did not deliver. I was looking at my watch the whole time throughout this movie as there was little to keep my attention.
summary: Was It Supposed To Be Funny?

reviewText: Man, I guess we as a people have just grown too spoiled. This is an excellent movie, from start to finish. Brad Pitt does more than hold his own here, and while there is some silly dialogue there are some genuine moments where I think he shines. Eric Bana as Hector portrays him superbly. The film just looks gorgeous all-around, and the fight scenes are impressive both in scale and intensity.People, there are a whole lot of worse movies out there. With all of the crap that gets made these days, we don't need to savage the good ones. A lot of people had problems with Brad Pitt as Achilles. So he doesn't always speak with the proper accent. Is that a reason to dislike the film so intensely? Pitt is one of the better actors out there, and rarely involves himself in lightweight, forgettable films. This a a true epic, and Wolfgang Petersen did a masterful job in covering the important parts of the movie when confronted with all of the material presented in Homer's Iliad. Hey, Peter Jackson tinkered with The Lord of the Rings, and I don't see a whole lot of backlash over that!I think that there are a lot of people today in this world who do nothing but criticize the works of others, and try to come off as cool in doing so, and that is what they think they contribute to society. I read Roger Ebert's review of this movie, and he was just appalled that the movie left out the whole "divine intervention" theme by the gods (Zeus, Poseidon, Athena, Apollo, etc. Roger, IT'S STILL A GOOD MOVIE! With movies like "The Chronicles of Riddick", "Alexander","Catwoman", "White Chicks" and anything starring The Rock floating around out there, you could certainly do much worse.
summary: Outstanding movie, don't listen to the "so-called critics"!
